answers.answer: Dear Charles,Triglycerides can be reduced with a low fat diet.  you may need the additional help of medication.  HDL may be raised with exeercise.  In view of your profile,  i would make certain that you do not have borderline diabetes.  This can easily be checked with a hemoglobin a 1 c.  you may wish to discuss this with your physician.your fatigue is not related to your triglycerides or HDL.

question: I have read several articles relating to this.  From what I understand, a high triglyceride level ALONE may not be a great contributor to heart problems...but combined with a low HDL can be.  My triglyceride level is 459 and HDL 25.5.Would a simple "low fat diet" help this (limiting my fat to 40- 45 grams per day)?  My Doctor gave a list of things to definitely not eat which amounts to almost 0 grams of fat allowed.I always heard the body needs a certain amount of fat to function, should I completely cut out fat??I have absolutely no energy, shortage of breath after exertion...would reducing the triglyceride level or raising the HDL level help this?Thanks,Charles
title: Triglyceride vs HDL
